api
Interface Space

All Superinterfaces:
java.rmi.Remote
All Known Implementing Classes:
SpaceImpl
public interface Space
extends java.rmi.Remote

Represents a raw computing resource where tasks ((Task) are automatically executed by registered workers as soon as they are dropped in. If a worker crashes, the computation would still continue (assuming there are other workers still running), since each task is executed under a transaction, which would be rolled back after the worker crashed, leaving the task in the space for another worker to pick up. For more information, please refer How to build a compute farm.

Author:
Manasa Chandrasekhar, Kowshik Prakasam

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Method Detail

put

void put(Task<?> task)
         throws java.rmi.RemoteException
The client decomposes a complex computation into smaller ones, each represented by a set of Task objects, and passes them to the Space via this method. In principle, these Task objects are processed in parallel by workers.

Parameters:
task - task to be added to the space
Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException - Thrown if any read/write errors occur during the process of adding a task to the queue

takeResult

Result<?> takeResult()
                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
After passing all the task objects to the Space, the client retrieves the associated Result objects via the take method. This method blocks until a Result object is available to return to the client. Thus, if the client sent 10 Task objects to the Space, it could execute: 

 Result[] results = new Result[10];
 for (int i = 0; i < results.length; i++) {
        results[i] = takeResult(); // waits for a result to become available.
 }

Returns:
One of the results obtained upon completion of individual tasks
Throws:
java.rmi.RemoteException
